status: shut down March 2022, context for understanding Steve's decisions at Nexus
priority: high - explains Steve's fears, drives his urgency, informs how he leads Nexus

company_overview.outcome: Shut down, returned remaining capital to investors, learned hard lessons

elevator_pitch.one_line: ML-powered analytics for B2B SaaS companies - predict churn, optimize pricing, automate insights.
elevator_pitch.problem: B2B SaaS companies have tons of data but lack time/expertise to extract insights. They're guessing at churn risk, pricing strategies, expansion opportunities.
elevator_pitch.solution: FlowMetric ingested customer data, used ML models to predict churn risk, suggest pricing changes, identify expansion opportunities, automate reporting.
elevator_pitch.target_customer: B2B SaaS companies (Series A/B), 50-500 customers, $1M-10M ARR, selling to RevOps leaders and heads of customer success

what_went_wrong.core_issue: Never found product-market fit - customers said 'interesting' but didn't renew

ml_black_box.issue: ML models made predictions but didn't explain WHY, customers didn't trust it
ml_black_box.customer_feedback: 'This is cool but I don't understand how it works, can't make decisions based on it'
ml_black_box.missed_lesson: explainability matters more than accuracy for adoption

wrong_customer_segment.issue: targeted Series A/B companies who had data scientists, didn't need FlowMetric's insights
wrong_customer_segment.reality: companies that needed help most (earlier stage) didn't have enough data to make ML work
wrong_customer_segment.catch_22: big companies had solutions, small companies lacked data, middle market too small

complexity_killed_adoption.issue: setup required data engineering work, took weeks to onboard, high friction
complexity_killed_adoption.customer_churn: customers signed up excited, got frustrated during onboarding, churned before seeing value
complexity_killed_adoption.lesson: if product requires PhD to use, market is too small

pricing_mismatch.unit_economics: couldn't profitably serve customers at price they'd pay

slow_iteration.issue: ML models took weeks to train and deploy, couldn't iterate quickly on feedback
slow_iteration.competitor_advantage: simpler non-ML tools could ship features weekly, FlowMetric shipped quarterly
slow_iteration.sarah_regret: over-engineered from day one, should've built simpler MVP first

january_2020.context: Steve left Stripe, Sarah quit Stripe, both confident after stable careers, startup was dream
january_2020.jordan_context: Jordan supported decision, they'd been dating 1 year, moved in together

march_2020.impact: fundraising became harder, customers cut budgets, harder to close sales
march_2020.steve_decision: pushed forward anyway, 'we'll figure it out'

july_2020.lead_investor: mid-tier VC (not top-tier, settled for whoever would invest)
july_2020.terms: $2M at $8M post-money, Steve and Sarah each had ~30% post-raise

august_2020_june_2021.team: grew to 8 people - 5 engineers, 1 designer, 1 sales, 1 customer success
august_2020_june_2021.customers: signed 12 pilot customers, mostly through Steve's network
august_2020_june_2021.excitement: everyone thought they were building the future of B2B analytics

july_2021_december_2021.churn: 5 of 12 customers churned, citing 'too complex' or 'didn't get value'
july_2021_december_2021.sales_stalled: couldn't close new customers fast enough to replace churn
july_2021_december_2021.team_morale: engineers frustrated by customers not understanding product
july_2021_december_2021.steve_stress: working 80-hour weeks, trying to find PMF, denying reality

december_2021.context: brief moment of calm, things seemed okay, planned Fall 2022 wedding
december_2021.jordan_perspective: Steve seemed stressed but said 'it's going well, just startup life'
december_2021.reality: Steve was lying to himself and Jordan, things were not going well

january_2022_march_2022.series_a_attempts: pitched 15 VCs, all passed, feedback: 'no clear PMF, growth too slow, churn too high'
january_2022_march_2022.team_departures: 2 engineers left for better-funded startups, morale collapsed
january_2022_march_2022.steve_breakdown: barely sleeping, snapping at people, Jordan begged him to take care of himself

march_2022.decision: Steve and Sarah agreed they couldn't raise Series A, better to shut down gracefully than die slowly
march_2022.returned_to_investors: $150k (7.5% of $2M raised - terrible return but better than zero)
march_2022.team: laid off everyone, gave 2 weeks severance (all they could afford), helped them find new jobs
march_2022.steve_emotional_state: devastated, felt like complete failure, questioned if he was cut out for startups

financial_summary.steve_financial_loss: 2 years of salary opportunity cost ($300k+), equity worth $0, savings depleted

team_impact.references_given: Steve and Sarah wrote recommendations for everyone, helped them network into new jobs
team_impact.team_sentiment: disappointed but understood, no one blamed Steve/Sarah, market was hard
team_impact.sarah_stayed_until_end: could've left for FAANG jobs during decline, chose to stay with Steve, loyalty proven

financial.savings_depleted: spent personal savings covering rent during low-salary months
financial.debt: took on $15k credit card debt to survive between FlowMetric and next job
financial.equity_worthless: 30% of $0 = $0, 26 months of work for nothing financially

emotional.identity_crisis: defined himself as founder, failure felt like personal inadequacy
emotional.imposter_syndrome: questioned if he deserved to be CEO, if he was just lucky before
emotional.relationship_strain: Jordan supported him but wedding delayed, Steve distant and depressed
emotional.family_guilt: Carlos working construction with bad back while Steve's startup failed - felt like he let family down

lessons_learned.product_market_fit_critical: no amount of execution fixes wrong product for wrong market
lessons_learned.simple_beats_complex: customers choose usable over powerful, even if powerful is better technically
lessons_learned.extend_runway_when_possible: should've cut burn earlier, extended runway to find PMF
lessons_learned.honest_conversations_earlier: should've admitted problems to investors/team earlier, tried to pivot sooner
lessons_learned.mental_health_matters: working 80-hour weeks doesn't help if you're building wrong thing, burnout killed judgment

professional.sarah_built_entire_product: architected system, wrote most code with 5 engineers, worked 70-hour weeks
professional.sarah_guilt: wonders if she over-engineered, should've pushed back on ML complexity, maybe simpler product would've worked
professional.sarah_reputation: 2 years at 'failed startup' on resume, but tech was solid even if business wasn't

emotional.failure_haunts_her: perfectionist engineer, FlowMetric failure is professional wound
emotional.loyalty_to_steve: stayed until end when could've left, that bond is unbreakable now
emotional.husband_david_tension: David watched her burn out, was relieved when FlowMetric ended, worried when she joined Nexus

lead_vc_relationship.name: Redpoint Ventures (fictional)
lead_vc_relationship.post_shutdown: Jessica was understanding but wrote off FlowMetric, unlikely to invest in Steve again
lead_vc_relationship.lesson: burning investor is reputational damage - even graceful shutdown doesn't erase loss

angel_investors.sentiment: most were understanding, startup risk is real, no hard feelings
angel_investors.one_exception: one angel publicly complained Steve 'wasted my money,' damaged Steve's reputation in SF

investor_relationships.marcus_not_involved: Marcus Rivera did NOT invest in FlowMetric - didn't know Steve then - learned about failure later when Steve pitched Nexus

what_steve_changed.validated_problem_first: talked to 50+ ops managers before building Nexus, confirmed pain was real and people would pay
what_steve_changed.no_code_focus: learned 'powerful but complex' loses to 'simple and usable,' made Nexus no-code from day one
what_steve_changed.simpler_tech: no ML black boxes - adaptive learning is transparent, customers understand how it works
what_steve_changed.honest_with_investors: told Marcus about FlowMetric failure upfront during Nexus pitch, no hiding past
what_steve_changed.smaller_team_longer: kept Nexus team at 8 people for 18 months vs FlowMetric grew to 8 in 6 months, extended runway

what_steve_didnt_change.still_works_80_hour_weeks: same workaholic pattern, still not sustainable, Jordan experiencing same neglect
what_steve_didnt_change.still_avoids_hard_conversations: hasn't told Marcus about 4-month runway, hasn't decided on Alex equity - same avoidance pattern
what_steve_didnt_change.still_optimistic_on_timelines: v2.0 March 2026 is aggressive, same pattern of hoping engineering won't slip
what_steve_didnt_change.still_defines_self_by_startup: Nexus failure would break Steve same way FlowMetric did - identity hasn't diversified

flowmetric_as_steve_wound.core_wound: Failure proved he's not as capable as he thought - imposter syndrome is real now
flowmetric_as_steve_wound.secondary_wound: Let down investors, team, Sarah, Jordan, family - guilt about wasted trust and time
flowmetric_as_steve_wound.hidden_wound: 2 years of life for nothing to show - turning 34 with $0 equity and credit card debt
flowmetric_as_steve_wound.drives_nexus_urgency: Must prove FlowMetric was anomaly not pattern, must succeed to validate those 2 years meant something
flowmetric_as_steve_wound.fear_of_repetition: Terrified of making same mistakes, sometimes paralyzed by over-analyzing decisions to avoid FlowMetric 2.0

flowmetric_as_sarah_wound.core_wound: Built perfect technical architecture for wrong product - engineering excellence wasn't enough
flowmetric_as_sarah_wound.secondary_wound: Should've pushed back harder on complexity, told Steve simpler was better
flowmetric_as_sarah_wound.hidden_wound: Watched team suffer from her technical decisions - feels responsible for 6 people losing jobs
flowmetric_as_sarah_wound.drives_nexus_perfectionism: v2.0 must be technically excellent AND simple - overcompensating for FlowMetric mistakes
flowmetric_as_sarah_wound.fear_of_repetition: What if she's building wrong thing again? What if Nexus is FlowMetric 2.0?

why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.steve_honesty: Steve told Marcus about FlowMetric upfront, explained what went wrong, what he learned
why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.lessons_applied: Marcus saw Steve changed approach - validated PMF first, simpler product, smaller team
why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.sarah_staying: Sarah coming back after FlowMetric showed Steve worth betting on again
why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.timing: 2023 market was better than 2020-2022 COVID chaos, Marcus believed timing was right
why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.gut: Marcus liked Steve personally, believed second-time founders who learned lessons often succeed
why_marcus_invested_despite_flowmetric.risk: Marcus knew this was riskier bet than first-time founder with no baggage, but believed in redemption arc

alex_kim_learned_about_flowmetric.how_he_found_out: heard through Silicon Valley network, someone mentioned 'Steve's previous startup failed'
alex_kim_learned_about_flowmetric.steve_didnt_disclose: Steve and Sarah didn't mention FlowMetric in Alex's interview - felt like deception
alex_kim_learned_about_flowmetric.alex_interpretation: 'If they hide major failure, what else are they hiding?' - trust partially broken
alex_kim_learned_about_flowmetric.reality: Steve didn't hide maliciously, just didn't think to mention it - assumed people knew
alex_kim_learned_about_flowmetric.impact_on_equity_request: Alex's doubt about Nexus success partly driven by FlowMetric failure pattern concern

jordan_lived_through_flowmetric.support_provided: held Steve through stress, encouraged him, made space for grief when it shut down
jordan_lived_through_flowmetric.cost_to_jordan: 2 years of Steve working 80-hour weeks, feeling like roommate not partner
jordan_lived_through_flowmetric.first_wedding_delay: Fall 2022 wedding postponed because Steve was recovering from FlowMetric shutdown
jordan_lived_through_flowmetric.current_fear: Nexus feels like FlowMetric 2.0 - same 80-hour weeks, same neglect, same 'just a little longer' promises
jordan_lived_through_flowmetric.breaking_point: if Nexus fails and Steve wants to do startup #3, Jordan probably leaves - can't do this cycle forever

apex_should_reference_when: Steve doubting himself - 'FlowMetric taught you what doesn't work. Nexus has $65k MRR and real customers. You learned. Apply it.'
Steve avoiding hard decisions - 'FlowMetric died partly because you avoided hard pivots early. Don't repeat that mistake with Alex or Marcus.'
Steve comparing to FlowMetric - 'FlowMetric had no PMF and $18k MRR peak. Nexus has PMF and $65k MRR growing. Different game. Stop pattern-matching.'
Steve paralyzed by fear - 'Yes, FlowMetric failed. That means you know what failure looks like. You're not there yet. Move.'
Steve feeling guilty - 'FlowMetric investors knew the risk. You shut down gracefully, returned capital, helped team land jobs. You did it right. Focus on Nexus.'
